Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: OSTARA: An Optically-based Simultaneous Transmit and Receive Architecture for Enhancing Wireless Communications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Improving the usage of communication spectrum resources is critical to future wireless systems. The OSTARA project focuses on the development of RF photonic techniques that support the ability to simultaneously transmit and receive in wireless devices. The effort involves a mix of theoretical development (specifically investigating potential improvements in capacity), as well as systems validation efforts involving building an opto-cancellation circuit capable of cancelling out co-site interference associated with simultaneous transmission and reception. . Specifically, the theoretical component of the effort will involve using ray-tracing to understand the role of cancelation of multipath components on communication rate, as well as an investigation into the impact of idealized cancellation on network capacity using graph coloring. The systems component of the effort will involve developing photonic circuits that subtract off the transmitted signal from the receiver chain, as well as potential multipath images of the transmitted signal. Validation will involve field testing the opto-canceller by setting up test scenarios on the ORBIT testbed at WINLAB.

Broader Impact: The proposed research will improve the spectrum utilization of future wireless systems, an issue of critical national importance. Additionally, the project will educate students and post-doctoral fellows in the inter-disciplinary area of RF-photonics as applied to advanced radio systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Today, there are more wireless devices on Earth than there are human beings. Global mobile data traffic continues to rise exponentially as our society consumes more high data rate applications such as HD video. Service providers are quickly hitting capacity in their networks, particularly in dense urban areas; you may have noticed back in 2012 when several major mobile carriers stopped offering unlimited data plans. To accommodate large population densities, wireless hubs and towers must be brought closer together, increasing interference between neighboring hubs. We are running out of breathing room, or spectrum, for wireless communications. 

The objective of project OSTARA, An Optically-based Simultaneous Transmit and Receive Architecture for Enhancing Wireless Communications, was to allocate more radio-frequency (RF) spectrum for wireless communications. We proposed achieving this objective by enabling a wireless radio to simultaneously transmit and receive on the same frequency band. Today's radios must either take turns transmitting/receiving, an approach known as Time-Division Duplexing (TDD), or transmit/receive at the same time but on separate frequency bands, an approach known as Frequency-Division Duplexing (FDD). The former approach is complicated and adds overhead as radios must incorporate handshakes and acknowledgements into their packet headers, while the latter approach takes twice as much spectrum as necessary. If we could simultaneously transmit and receive on the same band, our wireless communications would consume just half the spectrum we currently use. It would also greatly simplify wireless protocols, remove complicated handshake procedures, and enable truly global roaming. 

Why can't radios simultaneously transmit and receive? Just like humans, radios that attempt to simultaneously transmit and receive on the same band end up interfering with themselves - imagine trying to yell to your friend at the end of a long hallway while they yell back at you simultaneously. Can you understand each other? Likely not, because you can't hear your friend over your own yelling; this is a problem known appropriately as self-interference. Project OSTARA was about designing an optical system that could cancel self-interference sufficiently to the point that it would enable radios to hear weak signals of interest arriving from distant nodes - almost like a pair of noise-canceling headphones for your radio or cell phone. In the context of wireless communications, weak signals are often tens of billions of times weaker in power than a radio's own transmitting signal - the problem is actually much worse than the hallway example given above, which is why we must use optics. Optics offers us several key technological advantages that are extremely important to self-interference cancellation: wide bandwidth performance, high precision, low susceptibility to noise, and high tunability. In particular, compared to traditional RF approaches, which are narrowband and fixed, optics is wideband and highly tunable. These advantages are particularly important because today's wireless communications take place in multiple, often wide bandwidth channels. Today's LTE systems have bandwidths of 20-40 MHz but tomorrow's 5G systems are projected to require 100 MHz bandwidths, wider than what most RF systems can provide.

Spread across three universities, Princeton University, Rutgers University, and the University of Georgia, our efforts focused on building an optical simultaneous transmit and receive (STAR) system, integrate it into a semiconductor chip, and test it on a large radio network.
